This is one of the greatest games of all time, especially within its genre.

I bought this game when I kid not knowing what it was supposed to be. All I knew was that the game had some fifty game of the year awards and so I grabbed it. This was unequivocally one of the best decisions I ever made. 

Fellow oldheads will remember the incredible modding community that developed around it. Some of these mods I would love to see come back- They Hunger, Science & Industry...

Anyway, this game is so important and I love to revisit and play through it again and again.
this game made me live a half life, would recommend again

Half-Life era um jogo revolucion√°rio para sua √©poca, Gr√°ficos inovador e leve, rodava em praticamente qualquer computador de sua era.
A historia e inexplic√°vel de t√£o magn√≠fica, principalmente se levarmos em considera√ß√£o todo o acervo (Half-Life + Portal)
Com historias interligadas e super bem bolada.

Aguardamos pela chegada do Navio Boreal em Half-Life 3.
Obrigado Valve, e esperamos ansioso pela continua√ß√£o da Serie.

I decided to play this game having never really played any Half-Life games before. I was curious about it, a piece of gaming history that I figured I might try out for an hour. And 10 hours later I completed it. 

I get it now, I understand why this game was so lauded. The game feels shockingly modern. I was pleasantly surprised!

It can get obscure with its solutions from time to time, and I felt some parts dragged on a bit around the middle. But the puzzle elements generally do a great job at making you feel quite smart, like your scientist avatar. I think the game is exceptionally well-paced during the beginning levels. It feels fun to simply move and interact in the space. And I enjoyed many of the big and little moment that the game kept sprinkling throughout!

So, in conclusion, and in my opinion, the game that many have said is good... is indeed good. üëç

I'm a MIT graduate doing a postdoc in theoretical physics and I'm 100% convinced black mesa scientists actually have no brains. They are not capable of anything that can be called quantum physics or relativity, except in instances so vanishingly rare that they can be better explained by freak accident or sheer imitation.

It freaks me out. Having to work with them and watch them try to create things is like starring on a cooking show alongside a bunch of dogs, and the dogs just bark and breaks stuff, but everyone claps as if they're cooking too. They are just a couple of dogs. They are not cooking. They are not doing anything. But everyone is clapping, so you clap too, because you don't want to be the one to say it.
